I think the whole industry is looking for this one factor, right? This is like when I hear about the platform shift, you suddenly had this massive input device paradigm shift, right? We‚Äôre going from touchscreens or mice to voice and vision. I get that. No one has sorted out that form factor, so your bet is headphones.

Our bet is on headphones in the sense that we don‚Äôt necessarily have to retrain human beings as a whole with an entirely new form factor. And so I don‚Äôt have to change any behavior of sorts. Boom, tomorrow we can get you AI smarts immediately. And that, I think, is the promise. There‚Äôs a disconnect today with the possibility of AI and what it could be, and that‚Äôs where we see ourselves as designers, having that responsibility, or the opportunity, so to speak, to be able to design in such a way that we don‚Äôt necessarily have to change the entire behavior.

For what it‚Äôs worth, in the very early days, it could be, for that matter, a mouse. It‚Äôs just a mouse. Why is a mouse so important that today we‚Äôve brought it from a mouse all the way to a gaming mouse, and now the gaming mouse is a broader category than productivity, right? Gaming mice right now dominate the mouse category at this point in time. And right now, we can call it a smart headphone, and that‚Äôs the way we see it. We don‚Äôt necessarily have to retrain everybody to say, ‚ÄúOh, you‚Äôve gotta put on glasses. You‚Äôve gotta be able to bear with the weight,‚Äù and things like that.

So that is one of the things that we‚Äôre doing with Motoko, and a lot of the work that we do is actually on the software side of things, right? How do we ensure that we get context faster? How do we ensure that we are able to do all of that? So it‚Äôs both hardware/software fusion and a sense of fusion at the same time, that we are really focused on in terms of bringing the experience over. That‚Äôs something that we believe is the reason why people go, ‚ÄúOh, I absolutely get it, right now, why I would want something like that.‚Äù

So the model in the Motoko that I saw is ChatGPT.

It is ChatGPT.

Why‚Äôd you pick ChatGPT for the headphones and Grok for Ava?

So, ChatGPT for the headphones was primarily more from the premise that we think it‚Äôs a good assistant, in terms of CV capabilities, identifying things, and being able to give very quick feedback at the same time. But it could very well run Grok also at the same time. And the way that we are kind of presenting this is that whether it‚Äôs for Ava, or whether it‚Äôs for Motoko, or any of our other products, we are multi-model.

That was one of the things that we wanted to be able to do. We believe that at some point in time, you see Gemini doing really well. We see Grok doing really, really well. We see ChatGPT having advances in various aspects. This race to intelligence is just great for all of us as consumers, right? When I mention that Grok has great conversational AI, I think it is the best for conversational AI at this point in time. ChatGPT‚Äôs doing great, I think, in terms of it as an assistant, for reasoning and things like that. And that‚Äôs what we see ourselves. We see ourselves as owning the vertical from a gaming perspective, being able to work with all the best intelligence or the AI out there, and then bringing and designing a product or service tailored for our users, and within the gaming vertical.

So the vision is that I‚Äôm wearing headphones that have cameras, microphones, and speakers. I‚Äôm walking through the airport, and I‚Äôm just asking it, ‚ÄúWhere is my gate?‚Äù and it‚Äôs telling me the answer from ChatGPT. Or is it more that I‚Äôm sitting at my desk playing a game and it‚Äôs helping me through the game?

All of the above. You can literally do that with Motoko at this point in time.

But this is what I mean about the capability gap. I think if I walk through the airport and I ask ChatGPT where my gate is, it would not get that right at this point in time. Like, there‚Äôs a model capability gap there.

I believe that if you use ChatGPT today and you‚Äôre providing snapshots with some context, like, let‚Äôs say, location, to a certain extent, you could. I would be messaging on my phone with ChatGPT, for example, and it could give me the reasoning to be able to bring me there, to a great extent. I‚Äôll give an example, right? I would literally use ChatGPT for a whole bunch of day-to-day tasks and stuff like that. It‚Äôs got great reasoning; it‚Äôs able to do that. And now we are layering on vision capabilities, and that‚Äôs just another level of input.

Over and above, we‚Äôve got far-field microphones. So audio capabilities also come to bear. With all of this, we‚Äôre able to give a lot more information across to ChatGPT, which does all the reasoning, I think, for us. And that‚Äôs where we see it coming through. So constantly, the smart or intelligence is part of how we see us designing AI hardware, at this point in time.

It seems like you have a pretty big reliance on the models themselves, right? You‚Äôre obviously not training your own models. You wanna be multi-model, you wanna let people choose. Are you thinking of yourself more as being the best at the hardware, the form factor, and having the best microphones and cameras, and that will let people use the models more conveniently?

Well, we are an ecosystem, but I think for gamers. It‚Äôs not just, I think, in terms of the hardware, but most of our work is actually done at the software side. If I use CES as an example, if I‚Äôve got Ava, when I wake up, it‚Äôs giving me information like what‚Äôs happening in the day and what my day is gonna be today, so on and so forth. When I get out of my apartment, and I go out into the street, to the subway, et cetera, then I‚Äôve got Motoko at the same time. But with persistent memory, it will know exactly what has been happening in the home. Ava is somewhat following me everywhere in my day. I‚Äôm not gonna fall in love with it yet.

But in short, it‚Äôs following my day, I‚Äôm going around, I‚Äôm looking at it, I‚Äôm asking for directions. When I get to the office, I could literally still be with Motoko, which is another form factor. So the way that we see it is that the intelligence is persistent, and it follows you. The form factors that are presented are hardware form factors. It‚Äôs a little bit like how we‚Äôve designed our product at this point in time. We have a singular software platform where we are able to give you a great gaming experience, over and above. You could be using one of our mice, our keyboards, and so on and so forth, a laptop. These are just representations, at the end of the day. And that‚Äôs how we designed it, and there are particular problems that we need to solve that the models don‚Äôt provide for us. You know, context.

So that‚Äôs one of the things that our AI scientists do really well. We‚Äôve got advanced retrieval augmented generation (RAG), we‚Äôve got context, and we really focus on that. Persistent memory is something that we are very good at, at the same time. And these are fundamental problems that AI scientists need to solve. These are the things that our team does, so we work with the best models out there. And we also have the capabilities of creating physical representations, and that‚Äôs something that we‚Äôve got a huge advantage at.

Doesn‚Äôt a lot of the value here just accrue back to these models? And yet, even if you‚Äôre building all this stuff above the models and around the models to make them work the way you want, it seems like, ‚ÄúOkay, my Ava is gonna be powered by ChatGPT no matter what.‚Äù If I want that unified experience, I‚Äôm just kind of, at the end of the day, talking to an instantiation of ChatGPT all day long, right?

Because then I have Grok over here and ChatGPT in the headphones, you can‚Äôt unify that. So at the end of the day, it‚Äôs all Gemini, or whatever model I choose. So, can you provide enough value to charge a premium on top of the ChatGPT subscription to make that work?

So that‚Äôs, I think, where our angle is, from the software perspective. We believe that we can bring enough value of persistence across to the user, and progressively we will see even more users who will say, ‚ÄúLook, this is what I want, to be able to go from one model to another,‚Äù for example. Or if I‚Äôm happy with just a single model, and if I‚Äôm a techie and I‚Äôm happy to just go directly and play around with it, we provide that open platform. So being open is one of the things that we truly believe in.

One of the things you notice when you cover AI enough is the idea that the AI startups are just wrappers on OpenAI, and then eventually OpenAI will just eat them as the models get more incapable. We‚Äôve seen that play out already a little bit.

You obviously have hardware. Razer‚Äôs a different business, but you can see that dynamic here, where the core model capability might start to get the memory you‚Äôre talking about, where the core model capability might start to get the persistent personality across devices that you‚Äôre talking about. OpenAI is making hardware, we are told. There‚Äôs a competition with the core provider that is coming in different dimensions. How are you thinking about that?

Well, I think the entire tech industry has always been wrappers, for that matter, not necessarily from an AI perspective, but it‚Äôs the question of when you build a wrapper, do you provide enough value from the wrapper that you build? And that‚Äôs the thing, where it‚Äôs also very hard for anyone to be all things to all people. And I don‚Äôt think OpenAI wants to be all things to all people. I don‚Äôt think Grok wants to be all things to all people.

For us, we tend to be very focused on our vertical. We are not tempted to try to produce something else different at any point in time. And our vertical is really for the gamers. This is something we‚Äôve got huge domain knowledge in terms of what the gamers want, what the game developers want. We‚Äôve got distribution; we‚Äôve got about 70,000 game developers using our SDK. We‚Äôve got 150 million gamers on our software platform. We‚Äôve got distribution, I think, across to that. Can the models go out there and try to build the distribution? Yes, but do they prefer to partner?

And I think the answer is they do prefer to partner. Fundamentally, we have a huge amount of data, I think, on the gamers, their preferences, what they want, what they like, and that we can bring that across to the models at the same time, which is our IP, for that matter. I think with that in mind, as I say, having all these verticals, you may call it building wrappers of sorts, but these are very deep wrappers that we have to build. A lot of customization, a lot of building, and it‚Äôs more than just hardware, right? It‚Äôs not hardware.

As I say, the hardware is just part of the equation. It‚Äôs the software part that we need to do. It‚Äôs the R and D work that we need to do, for example, to get persistence in this space and context. So to get the context for our users, that‚Äôs where our data comes in at the same time, to be able to kind of pivot and focus on that.

I think one of the reasons people like companies like Razer, and like dealing with products that Razer makes, is that you just buy them and you‚Äôre done. Like you can just buy the mouse, and then you own it, and it‚Äôs fine. You can just buy the laptop. I‚Äôm not in an ongoing subscription relationship with you, unless I want to be.

Sure.

One of your competitors, Hanneke Faber from Logitech, came on the show a year or two ago, and she was like, ‚ÄúI wanna build a forever mouse,‚Äù and what she meant was a subscription mouse, and she‚Äôs never coming back on the show again, I think, based on the reaction to that. That‚Äôs my understanding of how they felt about that interview.

All the things you‚Äôre talking about are ongoing relationships, ongoing development costs. I hear it, and I hear the promise. I also hear, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna have to pay a fee every month.‚Äù Like this is where that comes from. You need to pay the developers, you need to pay for cloud uptime to make the AI system alive. How much are you gonna charge for all of that?

Well, we‚Äôve always had an ongoing relationship with our customer. That‚Äôs the thing, right? The way that we see it from Razer is that when somebody buys a Razer mouse, they tend to buy another Razer mouse in the future. They expand the devices that they own from us. So we‚Äôve always had a long-term relationship with our customer, from that perspective. At some point in time, as we think through the whole AI uptime, so on and so forth‚Ä¶ I mean, we‚Äôve had cloud costs also in the past, maintaining profiles in clouds. For us, I think that‚Äôs one of the things that we want to figure out. What can we do to ensure that we bring value?

I think that‚Äôs our obsession. If there is no value, our customers won‚Äôt pay for it, we won‚Äôt pay for it ourselves, right? So to that end, that‚Äôs our focus, I think, in respect of it. And it could be through‚Ä¶ We build into the hardware cost, for that matter, if that makes sense, and I‚Äôll be candid: We have literally not thought through this in great detail. But the way that we see it is, how do we identify that value to the user? And from there we are very clear, we message this. This is the value that we see out of this, and we‚Äôll let the market decide.

I look at that reaction from gamers, probably, to AI in the industry. There‚Äôs slop. I think there‚Äôs a lot of reaction to slop, and there‚Äôs a lot of reaction to game studios being in whatever amount of crisis the game studios appear to be in. There‚Äôs whatever reaction to consolidation. And then there‚Äôs the relentless fee seeking from the games industry, that everything is gonna be a subscription, everything is gonna be free to play with DLC, everything is gonna be an ongoing, recurring cost, over and over and over again.

The industry‚Äôs really moved to that model across the board, and I think people are feeling that pain. So then they hear AI, and they say, ‚ÄúOkay, someone else is gonna ask me for 10 bucks a month, or 20 bucks a month.‚Äù Can you avoid that? Can you just price it into the hardware? Is that going to be inevitable?

So, as I mentioned, I don‚Äôt know if we‚Äôre gonna price it into the hardware. We are still figuring it out. But I would say that, at the end of the day, the question is how much value are you getting on it, right? I mean, I pay for Spotify because I see the value in paying for Spotify. I get a whole library of music, and so on, and with Xbox Game Pass, so on and so forth.

There are times when I would prefer... I mean, I look back, and I go like, ‚ÄúOh, I wish I could just pay one time for this title.‚Äù There are microtransactions, there are subscription fees. But at the end of the day, I think, myself as a consumer, myself as a gamer, I would say‚Ä¶ I would just look at anything. I would say if it‚Äôs worth that amount of money to me, I would pay for it. Otherwise, I‚Äôll vote with my wallet. That‚Äôs the way I see it.

Are you seeing signs that the AI stuff is gonna be worth paying for that way? I mean, this is the bubble. We‚Äôre gonna spend all this money, we‚Äôll forward invest in all this infrastructure. We‚Äôre gonna skyrocket the price of RAM and GPUs, and then at the end of the day, people are going to say, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not actually worth the 20 bucks a month.‚Äù

I don‚Äôt necessarily see it as AI, per se, but I see the kind of value that I get out of it. So, for example, a ChatGPT subscription, or a Grok subscription, for that matter. I do see value in it, and that‚Äôs why I pay for it. And that‚Äôs the way I see it. I don‚Äôt see myself as paying for AI, per se. I see it as what am I getting out of a chatbot, for example, that can advise me on travel matters, health matters, whatever it is, my day-to-day, and stuff like that. Is that worth 20 bucks to me?

Because you‚Äôre a billionaire, right?

Sure.

I‚Äôm just saying, the marginal cost is meaningless to you.

20 bucks is still 20 bucks, that‚Äôs right.

I‚Äôm just saying.

Right.

I think for a lot of people, that is meaningful, especially stacked on top of all the other money they pay. Basically, I‚Äôm saying, do you see that critique of AI as a bubble? That the investment has not yet delivered the value that will make it so obvious that the investment‚Äôs worth it?

So I see that. I mean, huge amounts of investments are going into it. We are investing in AI, I think, as we speak. But I do see the potential at this point. In many cases, I mean, look at the number of paid subscribers for ChatGPT, for example. People do see the value in terms of whether it‚Äôs a chatbot AI, so on and so forth. I do think the potential is going to be realized.

Now, in many cases, I think there will be AI slop. I mean, I‚Äôve paid for subscriptions that, at the start, I thought were gonna be great, but I‚Äôve canceled them. But I do believe that in many cases, and in some cases that we have not even envisaged yet, the potential will be realized.

Let me ask you broadly, I mean, you obviously talk a lot to game developers. You and I actually were just talking backstage about the nature of art in the age of AI, and the nature of craft. That industry is going through an enormous amount of turmoil right now. What do you think the outcome looks like? What do you think makes that all feel good at the end?

I would say that the outcome that we see, and I think it‚Äôs gonna be the likely outcome, is that AI tools are gonna be helping human developers develop faster and better. And I think that‚Äôs the natural outcome, where we‚Äôre talking about graduating, whether it‚Äôs an analog kind of way of creating art versus digital. And I think it‚Äôs gonna be the same thing.

We‚Äôre going to see human artists use AI tools to kind of really bring their vision to life. We‚Äôll see new forms of artists, artists of whom may not necessarily have been so adept in terms of using a paint brush or using Photoshop, now being able to kind of wordsmith and craft great pieces of art with prompts throughout. So that‚Äôs, I think, what‚Äôs going to happen, where we will see even more human creators, now with the help of more tools.

Maybe I‚Äôm an optimist, but I really, truly see that AI tools will come to fall, because at some point in time, we‚Äôre going to see so much slop out there that we‚Äôre going to crave for really great art, really great design. And that‚Äôs what‚Äôs gonna happen. We‚Äôve seen a cycle go over and over and over again.

So, with the amount of slop out there, we‚Äôre going to see some level of art rise to the top, and that kind of art may still be created with the same tools that created the slop, but with great care, with great discernment, to be able to do something truly different. The difference will come from human ingenuity, not from countless prompt mashing, so to speak.

So I feel like I have to ask you this now. What games are you playing right now?

Oh, it depends.

What meets the bar?

What meets the bar? I play a lot of single-player games at this point in time, like Civilization and stuff like that. I still do a lot of that. I do play some MMOs of sorts, shooters, and I still play a lot of the battle royale genre. So things like that.

You just named genres. What games are you playing that meet the bar?

That meet which bar?

You‚Äôre talking about human ingenuity and creativity. What games are you playing right now that meet the bar?

Oh, well, I play random stuff. If you‚Äôre talking about human ingenuity‚Ä¶ I even play some of the Roblox games at this point in time, right? But a lot of the games, and maybe I talked broadly in terms of genres primarily because I appreciate the human ingenuity that‚Äôs gone into the genres themselves.

One hundred people dropped on an island with a circle that comes through. I mean, while I enjoy the game itself, I also appreciate the mechanics, the thought that has gone into them, and the premise that the designer has figured out. In PUBG, for example, it‚Äôs this primal instinct of humans to be the last man standing, so to speak. So it‚Äôs things like that that I appreciate, and I think it‚Äôs art.

Okay. What‚Äôs next for Razer? What should people be looking for?

More of the same, I would say, in the sense. When I say more of the same, I‚Äôd say nothing has changed from day one for us, and that has always been our mantra. And we used to say, all the time, that the mantra for us‚Ä¶ Our ‚Äúfor gamers, by gamers‚Äù mantra has really followed us from day one, where the gaming industry didn‚Äôt really exist as an industry, even the hardware industry or software, and so on and so forth.

We believe that we‚Äôve designed products for ourselves that we enjoy, that I enjoy using at any point in time, and that tomorrow, when the gaming industry grows dramatically, we will still be focused on games. Even though there are multiple opportunities for us to kind of expand out there. And even now, when we talk about the gaming industry in somewhat of a doldrums at this juncture, I believe that we‚Äôre gonna see the next great genre come through, right? Whether it‚Äôs MMOs in the early days, MOBAs, and then battle royales, we‚Äôre gonna see the next great genre. We‚Äôre hoping to see Grand Theft Auto VI at some point in time, right?

So all that, we look forward to, but we‚Äôre just pretty much laser-focused. It‚Äôs just that the demographic has really changed. The word gamer has also changed through the years. The games have changed through the years, right? For us, we‚Äôre just sitting here, very focused, and designing great products for ourselves.

Min, this has been great. Thank you so much for joining us on Decoder.

Thank you.

item.title: Hytale's first major update adds in dinosaurs, stops skeletons drowning and lets you have an early night
item.content:encoded:
Meanwhile, fire-themed creatures will no longer take fire damage, but can still catch fire

A first major update for Minecrafty block-build-and-basher Hytale arrived over the weekend, and it's added in some extra danger. There are now dinosaurs running around in the underground jungles. These are work-in-progress dinos, so who knows what might happen if you end up earning their big lizard ire. Also, the in-game bedtime's now half past seven.

These things and more can be found in the update's beefy notes. The dinos and other NPCs which now roam the underground jungles use "placeholder behavious" for the moment, and you'll need to generate some new unexplored areas in the biome in order to have them pop up.

Outside of that, some inhabitants of Hytale's blockverse have had knockback resistance added to them, the likes of foxes have been made less gung-ho about attacking folks, and fire-themed characters can't take fire damage. "Skeletons should no longer take drowning damage," developers Hypixel add, seemingly hedging their bets in case bony bathing continues to prove fatal on occasion. Kweebecs and Trorks have also had a couple of tweaks made to them.

Outside of those, a few extra options have been added to the character creator, while the audio/visuals attached to hitting and breaking various materials have been made a bit more crunchy. "You can now sleep starting at 7:30 PM" reads another noteworthy note, with Hytale's previous earliest bedtime having been 9:00PM.

As you'd imagine, the update's also heavy on key bug fixes and crash abatement, plus less glamourous quality-of-life tweaks like ensuring weapon attacks check for line of sight. Hytale being like Minecraft, you can of course also turn to mods for minor tweaks which eliminate any remaining annoyances official updates have yet to deliver. Or, you know, if you think the game needs several different variants of poo.

If you're still yet to give Hytale a go, we've got handy guides to the likes of setting up a server, getting it running on the Steam Deck, and hunting down key materials.

item.title: Emergency Crews Briefly Seal Off GTA 6 Studio Following Boiler Explosion
item.content:encoded:
First responders, including six fire engines, descended upon Rockstar Games‚Äô Edinburgh office, Rockstar North, early on Monday following reports of structural damage to the offices of the Grand Theft Auto 6 maker. The result of an apparent explosion of some kind, the incident thankfully left no one injured.

‚ÄúWe were alerted at 5:02 a.m. on Monday, 19 January to attend an incident on Holyrood Road, Edinburgh,‚Äù a spokesperson for emergency crews told The Herald. ‚ÄúOperations Control mobilized three fire appliances and specialist resources to the scene, where firefighters worked to secure structural damage at a commercial building. There were no reported casualties and crews left the scene at 9:21 a.m.‚Äù

According to Rockstar, the explosion was the result of a boiler malfunction and the studio remains fully operational as it prepares for the launch of GTA 6 in November.

‚ÄúEarly Monday morning, there was a malfunction in one of the heating boilers at Rockstar North,‚Äù a spokesperson for Rockstar Games told Kotaku in an email. ‚ÄúMany thanks to those that reached out with concern, and also to the police and fire crews who were on scene quickly to assess the situation‚Äìplease know that everyone is well and our studio remains open and operational.‚Äù

The office has recently been at the center of an ongoing labor dispute with 31 fired developers who were trying to unionize. The workers claim they were targeted for trying to organize while Rockstar maintains they were fired for violations of confidentiality rules, including leaking development and gameplay details in a union Discord channel with outside observers.

A judge reviewing the case recently denied the fired GTA 6 devs immediate relief in the form of back pay, but a full ruling on the overall merits of the complaint is still pending.

item.content:encoded:
• PC

Pre-orders open on January 22.

eastasiasoft will release a physical Tokyo Clanpool Uncut Edition for PC, the publisher announced. Pre-orders will open via Play-Asia and eastasiasoft store on January 22 at 7:00 a.m. PT / 10:00 a.m. ET, with shipping expected for early 2026. International shipping will also be available if ordered via eastasiasoft store. An Uncut Edition patch will also be available for users who have already purchased the game digitally via GOG.

Here is an overview of the Uncut Edition, via eastasiasoft:

This updated release of Tokyo Clanpool restores all the original content from the Japanese version of the game and will include faithful localization in English and Traditional Chinese text. Additionally, for those who already own the GOG release of Tokyo Clanpool digitally, an off-site patch will be made available to restore content that required removal from previous versions of the game. We have now officially confirmed the cancellation of Tokyo Clanpool‚Äòs release for Nintendo Switch in North America and Europe, making Tokyo Clanpool Uncut Edition for PC the definitive physical option for collectors.

Tokyo Clanpool is originally developed by Compile Heart and Idea Factory, and this Uncut Edition will be published exclusively by eastasiasoft. The game will be included on a uniquely branded USB drive along with a soundtrack CD, art book, poster, sticker sheets, acrylic character standees and numbered certificate in a collector‚Äôs box, priced at US$49.99 plus shipping. Fulfillment is expected in early 2026. Only 1,000 units will be produced. We have greatly appreciated customers‚Äô patience as this special announcement was being prepared.
